description: From Middle English chirken, cherken, charken, from Old English ċearcian (“to chatter, creak, crash”), from Proto-West Germanic *krakōn, from Proto-Germanic *krakċną (“to make a sound, crack”). Doublet of chark. Related also to crake, crack.

adjectives.description: chirk (comparative chirker or more chirk, superlative chirkest or most chirk)

entries.meaning: (colloquial, US, chiefly New England) lively; cheerful; in good spirits

verbs.description: chirk (third-person singular simple present chirks, present participle chirking, simple past and past participle chirked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, especially as "chirk up") To become happier.
(transitive, especially as "chirk up") To make happier.
To make the sound of a bird; to chirp.
